reviewText: If you are even slightly bothered by bright and obnoxious colors, avoid this game. 140 is full of excessively contrasting and bright colors, to an extent which can only be sufficiently described as obnoxious
date:
and there is no way to dim the game in the options. The degree of col♥♥♥♥♥♥ varies by level, but most of my experience was wrought with eye strain. For a very short game like this, you don't want a headache to be your lasting impression on the player.

Beneath the pain is a fairly enjoyable precision platformer. The game doesn't have any real 'puzzles,' aside from figuring out where you need to go and not flunking the jump (which happens often), but the integration of the music is the real selling point. Hitting a checkpoint adds a new instrument to the soundtrack, and a new mechanic to the level tied to that instrument, and the mechanic is then used to progress.

It's a very compact experience, taking only an hour or two and sticking closely to its minimalist aesthetic. However, the levels really drag on; there are only three of them, and if the game runs you two hours, that's about 40 minutes per level. It's not too bad at first, since the checkpoints are quite frequent and there's hardly any delay to respawning and trying again. If the game ended after the third level, with no extra content, this would be an overall positive review; however, completing the main game unlocks a set of 'mirror levels,' and the game falls apart then.

Firstly, the mirror levels invert all the colors, leading to even more obnoxious color palettes than before. Then you replay the same levels, butmirrored - an interesting idea, except now death starts you over from the beginning. Of what might be a 20+ minute level. Which will end with some sort of bullet-hell boss. And good luck spacing your jumps if you're trying to defend your eyes from a painful assortment of hot pinks and sun yellows.

You need to learn these levels deeply, and practice them often, and dedicate lots of time to completing them. This is the core problem with this segment of the game: it is a 1-2 hour experience that then demands significantly more commitment in order to 'complete' it. You don't HAVE to finish the mirror levels, but if you uninstall it then, have you really completed" the game? Since you need to complete the mirror levels to unlock all the achievements
recommended: it suggests the devs don't think you've won until you've gone through that hell.\n\nIf you are content to play only half the game
hoursPlayed: you probably won't regret it. But overall
voteText: 140 does not respect the player's time
helpfulPercent: and as a result I won't recommend it."

reviewText:
This is a fantastic little indie gem, and here's why.

The game is just a simple platformer which is based around the music playing in the background. The music helps drive the player into moving and jumping at the right times, to over come obstacles. The music is quite smooth and soothing electronic tunes. Nothing too extreme.

In each of the levels, you're main objective is to go along and acquire a small floating ball, which starts to follow you after you've bumped into it. You then take it to a 'point' which then changes the music playing, and how the level looks / flows. New areas are accessible, static objects start to move and even the gravity can change.

The best part of this game, in my opinion, are the boss fights at the end of each level. Each one is well thought out, and brings a challenge to the player fighting them.

It's quite a short game, around 45 minutes to an hour, if you just want to play the base 3 levels.

You'll get a lot more time out of the game if you choose to do the 'advance' levels, which are mirror worlds of the first three, without any check points. So it's a die once, start the level again situation.

Well worth the full price, which isn't asking for much in my opinion.

In conclusion:
The levels are well planned out.
Fantastic music, fits into levels nicely.
Simple, but effective use of abstract colours.
Fantastic boss fights.
8 / 10, still playing.

reviewText:
I really am enjoying 140. Minimalist abstract art and design at its best. Every puzzle is unique and rewarding. As I played I became more and more aware of the music until I was relying on it to progress.
140 is a game with no filler. You must use everything you're given to solve the puzzles. But at the same time, this game is not your enemy trying to make you fail while you battle against it to win (like in most games e.g. your typical shooter or racing game), it is there to guide you through by teaching you as you go. When a new element is introduced in a puzzle game, so often I am just left to figure out myself what to do with it. In 140, you are subtly shown the mechanics of new elements before you must interact with them. This allows the player to always feel confident and in control. As the complexity and difficulty increased at just the right pace, I began to find some puzzles had a bit more too them than they seemed. I would have to watch as the elements reacted to the music and learn their patterns. Some of the puzzles may take you a minute or two to complete, but you are never confused for more than a few seconds. It’s the perfect mix of mental and physical skill.
If you’ve enjoyed games like Thomas Was Alone or The Impossible Game you will probably enjoy this.
140/10

reviewText: A funky bopping music synced platformer that will have you jiving as you navigate a challenging three act game. Each act climaxes with a very unique boss situation. The third boss in this game will have you talking, screaming, crying, cringing and many other human emotions. The game leaves you wanting more and more. Though it is short lived in it's first three acts, it does offer countless more hours of entertainment with three more acts in mirror mode which harbors a no death policy. These three mirror stages are designed for those who have expert gaming controls and who like to punish/challenge themselves in the realms of 'Are you serious?' and 'What the Hell?' A pleasant eye candy surprise orchestrated with a top notch crisp soundtrack. Definitely a recommendation...

reviewText:
140-word review for 140:

Imagine a world of only two dimensions: length and height. Color that world with neon shades, sharp geometric landscapes and bind it together with minimalistic tech-house music. A world of stark beauty and remarkable simplicity; the player exists as a transforming piece of geometry - a square, triangle and circle altogether.

The geography of this flatland is not inert though. Environments comes to life in synergy with the music - music that is dependent on the player's progress in each of the three vistas. Can't make that jump? Well, the backing-track is probably missing an instrument; escorting a mysterious, floating orb to a docking station will add it to the soundtrack. Obstacles that were previously laying stubbornly static will come to life, rhythmically shifting all the way.

Glide, jump, roll, and shoot - 140 is an auditory and visual delicacy.

reviewText: I've never really questioned buying a game less than five dollars until now, and the more I think about it, the less this game justifies itself. Don't get me wrong, this game provides an interesting and unique experiance; however, that experiance is not increadably unique, nor does it last more than an hour or so. There exist other rythem-based platformers on steam, many of which are worth the money you spend on them. If you already want to buy this game, you'll probably enjoy it. Hell, if you know nothing about this game you'll probably enjoy it, but at the end of the day you'll be stuck with 3 (or 5, after the sale) bucks out of your pocket and a completed game that has no replayability. There are many other games you can buy for the same amount that will exceed this game on those terms. In conclusion, unless you have a super strong urge to buy this game, 140 is worth your time, but not your money.

reviewText: 140 is a 2d platformer that mixes challenging gameplay with amazing music but will you want to play 140 ? Theres no story in 140 but the game is amazing none the less. 140 consists of three stages and three reverse stages. In the game you go throught enviroments to get a ball that unlcoks a portal to the next level which changes the colour and the music of the part of the stage. The game Also has a simple art style that works. The game has boss battles at the end of each stage which all of them are a great challenge. The game also has a mirror stage that increases the difficulty and makes the game insanely difficult. Now for the bad. The game is incredibly short. Many of the extra hours are because of the tought sections of the game. The mirror stages will grant you a longer time of the game because theyre pretty difficult. Overall 140 is a fun and cheap game that i suggest you check out. 140 is a great platformer also has a great soundtrack. I give 140 a 8/10

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Don't pay full price.

If I remember correctly, I paid 5 bucks for this game. It isn't worth that much, even if it is only 5 bucks. The game is fun, and very interestingly designed. I love the rhythmic levels and it was a joy playing through them.

But the game is just too short. I beat the 3 levels in something under 30 minutes, maybe? My play time since then has been the mirrored versions of those levels. The mirrored versions are literally exact mirrors of the levels you already played, so there isn't anything really new or exciting.

The only difference is that dying in the mirrored levels returns you to the main area and you have to restart the level all over. If anything, that leads to a pain in the ♥♥♥ more than fun replay value.

So, initially, the game is enjoyable. And I would recommend you try it out. But get it for as cheap as possible. Spending 5 bucks on something I beat in 30 minutes and haven't really enjoyed since left a sour taste in my mouth.

Again, the time I played was enjoyable and intriguing. I just wish that there was more to it all.

reviewText:
This game is decent, when you have the patience for it...

...that being said, it's rare that you'll ever have the patience.

Since it's a game based on rhythm and patterns, you probably won't be surprised to hear that it gets very tedious and boring, very fast. And when you do get bored, or rage quit, because you've played one section 20 times over, because that millisecond screws you over, guess what? You'll have to play the whole level over again to get back to that point! If you need to take a break, you have to alt-tab, and come back later, or else you'll lose all your progress on that level.

This is especially annoying because the bosses are stupidly enraging, so if you get bored or rage quit, have fun playing that whole level to get back!

Really, all this game needs to be a great game is in-level saving, not just overworld saving.

Cons:

Overall:

This is a unique title with a lot of potential sadly squandered by poor execution. The final boss's pattern is so poorly designed as well that you can't even beat it via studying it's movements, as they are so erratic... This game tries to be Dark Souls but fails.

reviewText:
I almost never take the time to write a review of a steam game, most steam games I'm simply pleased with but not blown away, occasionally I'll write a positive review of a steam game I absolutely love. However, I don't believe I've taken the time to write a negative review of any steam game before this, so take all that into consideration when reading this review.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Forgive the caps lock but I had to be clear, this game is a very good example of what people mean when they call a game indie" as a pejorative. Is it lazy? Yep. Is it self congradulatory? Yep. Is it overpriced and exploitative in design such that it takes a lot of time to beat just because of bad game design choices? Yep.

Think what you will about "miminalism" but time and time again the indie community has shown that they believe it to mean "getting away with being lazy by calling it an artistic choice". This game uses solid colors like crazy
recommended: they are just solid colors. In every area of game design aside from the music (which is decent) this game cuts corners on production.\n\nFirst of all the mechanics consist of little more than basic "avoid hazards
hoursPlayed: time jumps". The hazards are a lazy static design. Honestly

reviewText:
Let me say that I completed the game and tried giving it a fair chance.

tl:dr Don't buy, the game is frustrating, has bad music, and is only 50 minutes long at most.

This game is extremely frustrating and miserable. The music is just straight up bad, and minimalism is used as an excuse for glitchy lo-fi tunes. In a good music based platformer you should feel like everything is moving naturally, and you should be moving in time with the beat. This game has you pausing to wait for a platform to reset constantly. And if you're a nanosecond off you will die.

The game also has 3 boss fights, each one more frustrating than the last. 1 is a bullet hell shoot, except you can only move slowly and jump, 2 is dodging an enemy that moves about .3 seconds before the beat, and the last one is like a rhythm game where you shoot in four directions...except that your aim moves away from where you are shooting ON PURPOSE, in addition to your targets moving at total random.

reviewText:
A great rhythmic platformer. You can cover the three levels in an hour, after which you can attempt to do them in mirror mode w/o checkpoints. This is the real test because when playing the levels for the first time, you can die as many times and therefore the importance of keeping the beat/rhythm may be lost on you. But when you play the levels in mirror mode, where every death sends you to the START of each level...you will learn how important keeping the beat is.

It is fairly priced for what it's worth. Challenging, but tight controls. Good music, but the graphics, quite honestly, are just simple (nothing great but nothing bad as well).

Recommended for precision platform lovers, or rhythm game aficionados.

reviewText: Like a weird marriage between Super Mario Bros. and Rez, this game will frustrate and transfix you at the same time: A rare and lovely combination.
cool little game <3

The Good:
Cheap
Minimal
Good platformer design and nice music
Interesting bosses

The Bad:
Short
Mostly too easy or too hard (checkpoints or lack thereof)

140 is worth a small price because it's a little bit of fun.  The platforming seems in sync with the techno-ish music most times and the minimalist approach makes for a good felling platformer.  It's just pretty short with three levels and their harder checkpoint-less mirror versions.

Worth playing once.

140 is a tough game to review. On one hand, the various challenges and gorgeous visuals all tied into the beat of each level is implemented perfectly, offering a blissful yet difficult platforming experience that will leave a nice impression. On the other, even with the 5 dollar price tag, paying that much is a stretch for the little content provided. Consisting of only 3 levels, each about 5-10 minutes in length, 140 is stretched out through its increasing difficulty and bosses, which can last multiple times longer than the levels themselves, even with generous checkpoints.

The game shines brightest in the platforming sections, implementing the mechanics I've mentioned before and having a smooth difficulty curve that is never unfair, as you always know when it's your mistake. The first two bosses as well are decently balanced and don't take long to adapt and beat, even after a few tries, but it is the third and final boss that felt more of an excercise of frustration than any sort of challenge.
There is a method to the third boss' madness, but you have to adapt to a lot of variables to beat this one, even after you finally wrap your head around the constantly changing mechanics after every checkpoint.

Beating this boss provides no payoff either, as there is no new content following, nor a nod to your accomplishment outside of the standard steam achievement. You do unlock mirrored versions of all three levels, which could be fun if they didn't turn off checkpoints. Getting all the way to a boss only to die and lose all your progress and gain elevated blood pressure is not my idea of fun. If you're excessively masochistic and want to have an awful day, go for those challenge levels, but otherwise 140 is a nice surprise that has some nice shining moments, even if it never lives up to its potential.

reviewText: A complete masterpiece, 140 questions modern gaming techniques, and is one of the more satisfying games you'll play this year. The entire game took me 45 minutes to complete, but I rarely got frustrated at bits, and just by closing my eyes and listening to the music, I was back on track to completion. This game takes us way back to the borderline arcade era, toying only with the level of difficulty throughout the different levels, but keeps it interesting by introducing a new way to interact with the world at each stage of completion.\nTurn up your sound, put your fingers on the arrow keys, and get ready to go through a completely psychedelic experience, without ever leaving your seat.

This game is fun...at first. If you're easily frustrated, do not play this game. You must be patient for the first 2 levels, and don't forget to pay attention! However, the very last stage is awful. It's practically impossible. So I recommend it for the first 2 stages, but after that, just stop.

Don't expect this to be a game that will blow you away, but consider it more like a game that'll make you rage quite a lot.

The graphics of 140 are simple and minimalistic yet powerful. It's quite the experience to play this game with headphones on or surround sound speakers - atleast it was for me. The game itself consists of 3 levels with 3 additional Shadow levels which can be played after you've finished the regular 3 levels. While the normal 3 levels are filled with checkpoints, the Shadow levels aren't - they're hardcore. If you die, you're out.

140 is a game that heavily relies on its awesome soundtrack. The idea is simple - jump, float and move following the game's rythm. An original idea, that Jeppe Carlsen (Creator of Limbo as well) worked out in an amazing and unique way, because this is probably the one and only time that this idea will stay unique.

I really enjoyed playing this short but powerful game. While I only clocked 3 hours, it felt like way more, and not in a negative way. This game is  a must buy for everyone.

A short but sweet platformer with a great movement-dependent soundtrack set at 140bpm (as the name shows). Quite difficult towards the end, but worth the ~45 minutes it takes to complete the 3 main stages.

A neat little platformer. Will take about an hour to beat. This is good because there is NO menu and NO way to save any progress.  Still, very fun and brief experimental little game. Worth a few bucks and an hour.

140 has to be one of the best visual looking games out. In 140 you play a square and you have to collect these coloured circles that makes the background come alive with bright colours and music come to life. The objective is simple collect all the coloured circles in each area and defeat the bosses.

140 has a brillant soundtrack and an intresting take of puzzle solving. The game was devloped by the brilliant mind of Jeppe Carlsen who worked on the multi award winning indie game Limbo.

However i did have one problem with the game everytime i pressed the Escape buttion the game faided to black untill the game quit on me but other than that its a minor problem.

Overall i give this game a hands down 10/10. A short but simple game.

Finally a rhythm action game where it all syncs up!\n\nYou're platforming around, but the timing of everything around you is synced to instruments of the current song. You can derive the timing rhythmically. The gameplay is good and the aesthetics are amazing.

★★★☆☆ (3/5 - Ok)

(WARNING: This review contains mild spoilers)

140 is a minimalistic puzzle-platforming game featuring unique, rhythm-based obstacles and a vast array of vibrant colours. 140 explores interesting concepts by combining platforming and rhythm features. Generally these features come in the form of timed jumps and moving to specific beats given by the background tracks.

I personally found these concepts unique and enjoyable but what let the game down for me was its lack of content. There are only three 10-20 minute levels (six, if you include the inverted levels) and there is a disturbing lack of instructions or information about anything going on when you begin the game (to be fair though the goal is easy to pick up once you get started).

In terms of story, well... there is none... but the gameplay and audio are the two aspects in which this game shines. You can tell that the musician that produced the upbeat soundtracks and catchy sound effects spent a lot of time perfecting it for the game.

The controls are quite smooth and handle well, this makes the difficult parts of levels somewhat more tolerable (especially the bosses).

In terms of replay value, you have the opportunity to play the three original levels again without checkpoints for a real challenge but apart from that there isn't really anything else to do in the game.

I would suggest getting this game if you feel like something different from your average platform game and have a decent hour or two to spare but apart from that I would give it a miss. I feel bad about rating this game negatively but I felt it didn't live up to the expectations I got from reading about the game before I installed it.

reviewText: Great and simply game! Absolute gameplay and atmosphere! Many Large videogames studios should learn from this game how to accomplished FUN!

2 hours of exhilarating & pulsating fun is how this rhythm game can and should be described. People have different tastes, of course, but for lovers of puzzles and those who don't mind a bit--only a bit because this game isn't THAT difficult--of mental workout, 140 is a winner. Screens are simple, colorful--you might even wanna snap a couple of them and use them as wallpapers on your HD LCDs (I did)--and reverberate with pulsating beat music. Game's beat music is the key to way forward, because you will need to time your moves in rhythm with these beats. Puzzles are intelligently crafted and made me laugh in amazement when  I figured them out. There are, in total, three levels, and at the end of each level, you are challenged with a boss screen. The third level, however, has two boss screens, the last one of which is a disappointment since it is solvable with a fixed sequence of key presses however many times you play it. I like this game in particular above many other puzzlers as it doesn't test you on how fast you are at your keyboard, but instead challenges your patience and alertness by offering you unlimited time for each puzzle piece. 9/10.

I like the concept of this; I'm a huge fan of games that are heavily tied into the audio. The objective is to gather multi-colored orbs and bring them to these half-circle zones nearby. Each orb adds more complexity to both the soundtrack and the level, and opens up more of it. While the controls are pretty simple, some of the platforming does require perfect timing. Platforms move and/or disappear in time with the music, which actually helps, because it allows you to work out the timing required.

At least in the first three worlds, there's no penalty for death. You simply start back at the last checkpoint. I'm not sure if that continues on. It can be kind of frustrating, since some of the timing does need to be precise, and the boss fights can take a few run throughs to work out the pattern.

I enjoy the music, which is pretty beat-heavy electronica. I do think this is one of those games that would not be kind to anyone with any sort of photosensitivity; the visuals aren't quite neon, but they do tend to change and flash with regularity.

A rather fun rhythm based platformer that will last you an hour but you will have a good time during that hour.

You must move around the environment, avoiding obsticles in time with the rhythm in order to proceed to the next area and defeat a boss.

The game has no interface or menus, it just plonks you into the game and you have to figure it out yourself. You have a sort of mini hub world for choosing levels but that's about it.

After completing the game you unlock the levels in reverse which must be completed in one go (a death will take you right to the start of the level). This feels like padding for what is ultimately a very short experimental game and will only ever be completed by the hardcore dedicated fans of the game. I myself found it not worth the effort.

I enjoyed the game, I hope the developer is continuing to make games as I did enjoy this one, it was just over too quickly and didn't exactly leave a huge impression on me.

Curiousity pushed me forward into this interesting indie experience and before I knew it, I was playing the most rhythmically synced platformer I've ever experienced.

140 is a great minimalist, hardcore platforming game with a unique twist: the level changes to the beat of the music. Platforms will appear, grow, shrink, move, blink out of existence, or become deadly to touch at the beat. Walls and hazards will rhythmically turn on and off. It's really very cool. You are an entrepid little monochromatic shape braving the dangers of the three levels and overcoming the bosses at the end of each. If you manage to beat them all, you will be granted an even more challenging adventure (and seriously, the last boss is a huge jerk. Like, really really mean.) I just beat the entire game (and unlocked all achievements, which was nice), and it took me about 6 hours, which is impressive considering if done perfectly, you could probably do the whole game in less than 15 minutes. I think it was worth the money spent.

I love the simplicity of the game's graphics, controls, and objectives, I love the precision and timing involved, and I love the music for this game! The only thing I can think of that I don't like about this game is what happens when you die... I die a lot, and every time it happens I jump out of my chair... If you like heart attacks, seriously pick up this game.

As a final note, this game is on sale ALL THE TIME. you can either wait and grab it for $1-$3, or support the dev and maybe help them get more games out by paying full price, which I recommend.

2 hours of exhilarating & pulsating fun is how this rhythm game can and should be described. People have different tastes, of course, but for lovers of puzzles and those who don't mind a bit--only a bit because this game isn't THAT difficult--of mental workout, 140 is a winner. Screens are simple, colorful--you might even wanna snap a couple of them and use them as wallpapers on your HD LCDs (I did)--and reverberate with pulsating beat music. Game's beat music is the key to way forward, because you will need to time your moves in rhythm with these beats. Puzzles are intelligently crafted and made me laugh in amazement when  I figured them out. There are, in total, three levels, and at the end of each level, you are challenged with a boss screen. The third level, however, has two boss screens, the last one of which is a disappointment since it is solvable with a fixed sequence of key presses however many times you play it. I like this game in particular above many other puzzlers as it doesn't test you on how fast you are at your keyboard, but instead challenges your patience and alertness by offering you unlimited time for each puzzle piece. 9/10.

I think this is a good game, but I don't think everyone would think it's worth full price. The game took me about 70 minutes to complete. There are only 3 levels. The graphics of 140 are simple and minimalistic yet powerful. It's quite the experience to play this game with headphones on or surround sound speakers - atleast it was for me. The game itself consists of 3 levels with 3 additional Shadow levels which can be played after you've finished the regular 3 levels. 140 is a game that heavily relies on its awesome soundtrack. The idea is simple - jump, float and move following the game's rythm. An original idea, that Jeppe Carlsen (Creator of Limbo as well) worked out in an amazing and unique way, because this is probably the one and only time that this idea will stay unique.

I really enjoyed playing this short but powerful game. While I only clocked 3 hours, it felt like way more, and not in a negative way. This game is  a must buy for everyone.

Really was surprised by this game, it's short but really well crafted. Honestly the closest I think I've ever played to a true rhythm platformer and that's what makes it so strong; the rhythm elements are well-implemented and the level designs use them effectively without ever unfairly. The game's honestly not too difficult to clear normally, though the reverse stages certainly present a bit more of a challenge. The bosses also tend to break the mold of the game, though they're not too challenging once you figure out strategies for them. The minimal graphic style I'm neutral on; doesn't detract from the game but doesn't add to it either, it's just there and I'm fine with that.\n\nOverall though, a neat little game that I'm glad I played.

A fantastic ,simplistic and challenging yet way too short platformer. This is the kind of game you really learn to love for what it is. The kind of game that makes you pray that the developer surprises you again with such a magnificent gem.

You may probably think that the name of the game has nothing to do with the actual game. But truthfully, it means that you are able to shapeshift into 3 different kinds of shapes: Square, Triangle, and Circle.

Yeah I dont f***ing know.

THE REVIEW-

Everything this game has to offer is given through powerful musical tunes in the background. All of the enemies (obstacles) are presented with unique consquences to bypass. If you fail, you may get mad. If you fail more than once after failing prior to the second time, you will be prone to ragequitting.

The beats are solid and energetic, as well as the entirety of the game. One thing that may ♥♥♥♥ off many players who dare challenge their minds to this near-impossible work of art, is the frequent need to have a long walk from your last checkpoint. While in mid-game, checkpoints become more subtle and unreasonably missing- as to add more difficulty to the hand-sweating completionists' necessity to quit.

Remember, even if a game like this pisses you off most of your journey into it-
just remind yourself of those hand-sweating completionits who have to go through the whole game spending 5+ hours on it, regardless of its length/duration.

***8/10***

-Hand-Sweating Completionist

This game is purely awesome. But to say more, any computer can run it at max settings, and the game itself and the achievements have various easter eggs as well that normal people don't really notice.
(SPOILTER ALERT)
1. The title 140 refers to the tempo of the sound track... which is 140BPM
2. The normal achievements (level one for example) are the binary representation of 140-(level)
3. The other achievements are the reversed binary representation of their respective levels, as they play right-to-left instead of left-to-right, and it's YOLO mode. This makes it so it's not only a different experience, but YOLO mode is gauranteed to make you RAGE.
Really great concept and execution, but when I was done I felt like I had only finished a tutorial—would love to see an expansion/sequel with exponentially more difficult puzzles.

reviewText: Incredible challenging and simple at the same time. The visuals and the audio presentation work together flawlessly. Quite an unforgettable experience. Prepare your jaw for some major droppage.

140 is a rhythm-based platformer that challenges you with increasingly difficult stunts as your geometric character progresses through the game. Each time you complete a segment you save at a checkmark, which makes it less painful when you fail over and over again. Some people may struggle with the timing or precise controls required to complete some of the challenges, but I wouldn't call any of them impossible.

Most objects on the screen, besides your character, are simple squares. It doesn't get much simpler than that, but somehow it works. The graphics are vibrant and trippy at times, moving and changing colors to match the electronic music. The music by the way is fantastic! As you complete chapters and other key parts of the game the music will shift to reward the player with some awesome sounds.

My only complaint is that the game took me less than 90 minutes to complete. When you complete the 3 main acts (which takes 1-2 hours),you unlock the same 3 acts, but in reverse and without checkpoints. This should provide me some extra play time, but I'm certain that I will get frustrated and give up without the checkpoint handicap. So for that reason, the game doesn't have much replay value and the campaign is short, so I would only recommend this game if you find it on sale for $1-2.

If what did you see in trailer has caught your eye - prepare for ~1 hour of pure diamond, rhythm-jumping puzzle based platformer. (which has its fair set of unique brain teasers, with every last one of them laid out in perfectly smooth progression of the last trick you've learned)

My only gripe would be that, as a music rhythm-based game, it sometimes punishes your haste as it requires sharp timing of your movement (but nowhere near as frustrating as, say, N+" videogame does) and you just don't want to stop the flow.

But the last boss fight (along with the end

140 is a tough game to review. On one hand, the various challenges and gorgeous visuals all tied into the beat of each level is implemented perfectly, offering a blissful yet difficult platforming experience that will leave a nice impression. On the other, even with the 5 dollar price tag, paying that much is a stretch for the little content provided. Consisting of only 3 levels, each about 5-10 minutes in length, 140 is stretched out through its increasing difficulty and bosses, which can last multiple times longer than the levels themselves, even with generous checkpoints.

The game shines brightest in the platforming sections, implementing the mechanics I've mentioned before and having a smooth difficulty curve that is never unfair, as you always know when it's your mistake. The first two bosses as well are decently balanced and don't take long to adapt and beat, even after a few tries, but it is the third and final boss that felt more of an excercise of frustration than any sort of challenge.
There is a method to the third boss' madness, but you have to adapt to a lot of variables to beat this one, even after you finally wrap your head around the constantly changing mechanics after every checkpoint.

Beating this boss provides no payoff either, as there is no new content following, nor a nod to your accomplishment outside of the standard steam achievement. You do unlock mirrored versions of all three levels, which could be fun if they didn't turn off checkpoints. Getting all the way to a boss only to die and lose all your progress and gain elevated blood pressure is not my idea of fun. If you're excessively masochistic and want to have an awful day, go for those challenge levels, but otherwise 140 is a nice surprise that has some nice shining moments, even if it never lives up to its potential.

A rather fun rhythm based platformer that will last you an hour but you will have a good time during that hour.

You must move around the environment, avoiding obsticles in time with the rhythm in order to proceed to the next area and defeat a boss.

The game has no interface or menus, it just plonks you into the game and you have to figure it out yourself. You have a sort of mini hub world for choosing levels but that's about it.

After completing the game you unlock the levels in reverse which must be completed in one go (a death will take you right to the start of the level). This feels like padding for what is ultimately a very short experimental game and will only ever be completed by the hardcore dedicated fans of the game. I myself found it not worth the effort.

I enjoyed the game, I hope the developer is continuing to make games as I did enjoy this one, it was just over too quickly and didn't exactly leave a huge impression on me.

I'm a big fan of rhythm games, but this one does need to be recognized as a niche target audience.

The fairly steady technopunk(i'm not sure of the exact musical flavor) rhythm and enough checkpoints keep the game from being overly challenging. Instead of rushing through (which will certainly result in several deaths), most sections of all the levels almost REQUIRE you to pause and wait for the path to become clear. In some ways this is enjoyable, as it emphasizes the mental reasoning over twitch reflexes, but it can also come across like driving down a highway and hitting every light red; even if there is absolutely no rush, it gets frustrating.

Everything in the game is responsive to different track sections that the player activates to progress through the game, but the caveat to this is that while the level is perfectly in time with the music, this actually requires the character to move OUT of sync with that same music. Instead of jamming to the beat, you're really jamming in counterpoint, almost like you are actually fighting against the track. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but for those who have grown up on or mastered DDR, Guitar Hero, Elite Beat Agents, or even games like Audiosurf or the Bit Trip series, will find themselves getting a number of annoying flase starts when they try to move to the music and match it's timing.

The controls are smooth, and incredibly simple. This could easily translate to a smartphone, using the gyroscope for movement and a single button press to jump, or the bottom half of the screen split for left and right movement, with the entire top half of the screen as a big jump button that the thumb for the inactive direction can press.

It only has 3 levels, which are then recycled into mirror levels that strip out all the checkpoints for extra challenge. There are Boss battles" and I really enjoyed the first and second battles for these

In short: a supershort* music game with platforming, minimal graphics and ever-changing mechanics that you need to adjust to (which is the main draw). Really inventive, and visually very strong.

Fairly short rhythm platform game.  It took me a bit to figure out what was going on, given that I initially saw a solid black screen with a single white square in the center that I could change into a triangle or circle with no obvious effect.  Once the game got going, however, I finished what appeared to be the whole thing in two sittings.

The music is fun, and nearly central to the game play.  (I haven't tried playing with the music off; watching the background might suffice, but I wouldn't recommend it.)  Graphics are minimal, but represent the world well, once you understand what they mean.  (How long before the world forgets what static looked like, though?)  Puzzles are occasionally challenging, with one lengthy battle (for lack of a better word) at the end of each level.

I'm not sure I can justify paying full price, but on sale it's a nice little piece.

Quite possibly the best artistic rhythm game I've played.  It's simple, gameplay progresses brilliantly while teaching you everything you need to know without a single bit of text, and music is an integral part of the game instead of a thing that merely happens to have beats at the appropriate times.\n\nIt is sadly very short.  Buy it if you're interested in the experience, and/or want to see how phenomenally well-designed levels play, so you can wonder where most other games go wrong.

140 is a side scrolling game where the objective is to complete levels while avoiding and/or jumping over obstacles.
The game itself is not actually very long. I bought it a long time ago on humble when it was on sale. It took me like an hour and half to complete. It has primarily 3 levels. To complete each level, you have to pass a series of smaller obstacle avoiding courses and capture a ball-thingy and take it back to the capture point (think of it like Capture the Flag mode, where you have to capture and take the flag to a capture point, except in this case, the flag is a ball).  The game primarily relies on following rhythm to jump and/or avoid obstacles. The soundtrack is pretty awesome, I wish I could get it outside the game. All the puzzles have rhythm which once you get a hang of is a breeze to complete. Fortunately, the game does not end there. With in each level, the rhythm and obstacles change often enought to give you some challenge.
In all there are actually 6 levels, (3 main, 3 repeated excepted tougher levels). The difference is that the three main levels have checkpoints spanned over levels to give you a chance to resume if you screwed up. The 3 repeated levels do not have checkpoints so you have to finish them without making a mistake or you will have to start over. As I said, the 3 main levels took me like an hour and a half tops, so its a very short game in that sense.
Also warning, this game has colours flashing like crazy so if you are prone to having seizures or headaches, I would recommend avoiding this game. I had occasions where my head would suddenly hurt from all the bright colours flashing on screen.
All in all, its a decent pick if you get it on sale. Its definitely worth the hour or two you spend on it.

This game's graphics are very simple and basic, which I'm sure is intended.  Ultimately things are paired back so much that I couldn't justify much time with this game.

Disappointing and frustrating. This game has a very interesting premise, but the execution is poor. The result is infuriating and tedious trial and error that saps all life from the game. Consequently, it isn't nearly as fun or interesting as the trailer makes it out to be; and though the music is good, even *that's* not as fun or interesting as the trailer makes it out to be. This game *very* quickly becomes a chore; every so often I forget how unenjoyable it is, and launch it. I rarely play for more than five minutes before I remember why I don't like this game. Which is a shame, because I really wanted to like it.\n\nThe game is also too short and minimalistic for me to condone the price. The three sudden death mirror levels" you can access after completing the three basic levels make it longer

This is an ethereal-yet-decadent dessert the size of your pinkie nail. Delightful, but over far too quickly, and the maitre d' is giving you a Pointed Look. Three levels is a bit short for $5, and the challenge of doing them over again in mirror-image without even one mistake and an eye-gouging colour scheme is the most exhausting kind of padding. Still, it was an hour's entertainment, and I've spent $5 on much briefer and more foolish diversions. Definitely buy if it comes up on sale.

A very minimalist platformer where the environment reacts to the rhythm of the music, or perhaps forms it. The sound design is exemplary, the obstacles are challenging but not frustrating in the slightest, every mistake is very much my own. Even the one-hit KO versions later in the game are a wonderful experience. I could sit and play this all day if I didn't have to eat, sleep and work. Sublime.
pretty fun

140 has no interface, no hud, nothing to configure before you play. You are simply thrust into a digital world that somehow manages to be beautiful in spite of its minimalism. The objects you encounter and music you hear blend perfectly to form the trance-inducing rhythm of the game. And with perfect timing, the developer snaps you right out of that trance to present an unforgettable moment. I found my jaw dropped on more than one occasion; which is saying a lot for a game about circles, triangles and squares.

I f'ing can't stop playing this! The core game is a bit short, but very intense! A lot of ideas explored in a short period on time with no fillers! And if you want to go nuts there are still the mirror stages (think marathon) to play.

I purchased this game in a humble bundle for 33 cents knowing nothing about it.  I was quite pleasantly suprised.  The music pulled me in right from the start screen.  Curiousity pushed me forward into this interesting indie experience and before I knew it, I was playing the most rhythmically synced platformer I've ever experienced.

Every moving element has a sound tied into it with the background music, allowing you to time your actions to a tee.  It's an aurally immersive (albeit short) experience that's worth the price of admission.

Gamepad recommended.

140 is an entertaining platformer with a catchy beat.  It's got a VERY forgiving autosave system with infinite lives, so you won't get overly frustrated if you happen to hit a spot where you get killed a lot.  If you have any experience with platform gaming at all, you should breeze through the majority of the game, including most of the level bosses.  I personally found the end boss a bit annoying since the pattern shifts were making my head implode, but it was still good fun.  Worth a buy for the music in the game at the least.  Since it's got a really short play time from start to end (30-60 minutes) even when you count failing on the end boss multiple times, I'd wait for a sale to grab it.

Short description: rhythm platformer.

Think about Mega Man disappearing blocks. Think about precision platformer, with moving elements synced with the background music beat. Think about an entire game exploring this concept.

Each new challenge shows up only once or twice, so the game never feels repetitive. The developer chose to make a short game (about 1 hour) instead of artificially increasing its length by repeating the same things over and over, which is a great decision in my opinion.

For hardcore gamers, there are also achievements for completing each stage without dying.
Play this game with a good set of headphones and prepare yourself for a trip. Loved it. Loved the mirror stages and the challenge they presented. I wish it was longer!

I just played through the game in around 45 minutes. It's polished, innovative, clever and it leaves you feeling satisfied with the experience. It consists of three levels of rhythm based platforming that increase in difficulty with a boss" at the end of each level. This is what took me around 45 minutes to play and was very well paced. After you complete that half of the game you unlock a second half which is a modified version of the first half but with everything mirrored and with no checkpoints so you have to start from the beginning if you make a mistake. This hardcore mode is a nice addition for people who enjoy the game and want to perfect their own gameplay vs. this small but perfect game."

A simple platformer that tests your timing and reflexes.  The normal levels are quite fun but the hardcore levels can be a bit frustrating.  Grab this game when it is cheap for a quick little challenge.

140 is a minimalistic platformer with a killer soundtrack. As you navigate your polyhedron through the stark landscape, the obstacles shift in time to the music, and often contribute to the building soundtrack. It's hard to explain how well this all comes together to pull you into a trance while you try to jump and dodge traps, pits, and moving blocks. The boss fights really step up the game, and put a spin on the fundamentals learned through each of the game's 3 levels.\n\nWhile 140 runs a bit on the short side, it more than makes up for it with style, clean and engaging gameplay, and a brilliant music-game interaction. Absolutely worth a few bucks if you like any of the words above.

this game needs to win more awards...because i played it ...and omg... its so fresh and awesome... i mean i know its a minimalist platformer...but its ALL SO SMOOTH and responsive... you just have to pump up the volume and let the music flow through you ... then the game is ''easier''\n\nthe visuals are superb and the soundtrack is simply catchy and amazing
